text: In Python 2.6 (or earlier), use the dict constructor:

code: d = dict((k,v) for (k,v) in blah blah blah)

text: In Python 2.7+ or 3, you can just use the dict comprehension syntax directly:

code: d = {k : v for k in blah blah blah}

text: in py3k dict comprehensions work like this:

code: d = {k:v for k, v in iterable}

text: in py2k you can use fortran's suggestion.
Use python dict comprehensions: Here's the link to know more about it: Dict Comprehensions
